druid.emitter.logging.logLevel controls the logging level of the emitter (for metrics). This should work, at least in my local dev env. If you want to change the log level for all console output, this configuration will not affect things.

Thanks for the clarification @fjy , just so I make sure I understand, setting druid.emitter.logging.logLevel is only intended to control one specific Logger instance, rather than control com.metamx.common.logger.Logger overall. Is that correct?

Yes, specifically, it should only apply when you set your emitter type to
logging (the default). See LoggingEmitterConfig.

Duplicated by #614
How will we know how many total queries have been issued against histoircals?

The intent is that the number of request/time metrics will be the number of requests issued to the historicals, and the number of query/time metrics will be the number of segment scans performed by the historicals. Each request/time metric should contain the time taken to handle one http request. Each query/time metric should contain the time taken for one segment scan.

Hi @nergdron, can you share an example of what your logs look like? Druid uses log4j under the covers and our logs generally prints the class that contains the log message.

Hi fjy,

That's the problem, really. It prints the class used, but on startup, most of the components do the same init on the same classes (such as jetty), and so their log messages get mixed together. This means if there's a problem, it's very difficult to tell which component the issue actually came from. Even if the log message could include the process PID, that would be helpful in separating them, although the component name would be more visually useful.

I'm out of the office at the moment, but I'll get you some log messages showing this when I get back.

Graeme

PR #705 should address this for points at the end of the data interval, like your case, but interior points will still be zero-filled.

By "zero-filled" I mean that if you have data in minute 0 and minute 2, but not minute 1, and you do a minutely granularity query, then minute 1 will be filled in with a zero even though there are no data points for that minute. By "interior points" I mean time buckets that are contained within minTime/maxTime, even if they don't have any actual data in them.

I think that groupBy queries do not do any zero-filling at all, but timeseries queries do for interior data points. I guess whether they should or not is something of a philosophical question.
It has been suggested that we should be temporarily setting the current thread's context class loader when calling hadoop methods.
@pdeva I believe this is the same bug we just fixed with #703. Can you try again using Druid 0.6.150?

A possible workaround is to specify a granularity of type "period" with a period of "PT3M", with the same origin. PeriodGranularity should not be affected by this but, since it uses a different algorithm to truncate timestamps.
As far as the timestamps are concerned, the granularity timestamp truncation is always relative to time zero (a.k.a. Jan 1 1970 UTC), and not relative to the query interval.

So this is indeed a bug then.

Using the example in the first post, if I specify 17:46 as the origin, I should see the granularities in the first list that i was expecting right?

You are specifying your granularity period incorrectly, you need to replace the `duration` field with `period`, i.e.

```
"granularity": {
    "type": "period",
    "period": "PT6M",
    "origin": "2014-08-30T21:47:00.000Z"
}
```

To answer your second question, yes if you specify 17:46 as the origin, your timestamps will go in increments of 3 minutes starting at 17:46.

You can make changes to the console without re-deploying by providing the path to the static resources using -Ddruid.coordinator.console.static=file:///path/to/static/files
That will override the resources provided on the classpath.

Working with `hyperUnique` aggregators requires using the `hyperUniqueCardinality` post-aggregator to convert the HLL sketch into a number. See http://druid.io/docs/latest/Post-aggregations.html for more details on how to use the HyperUnique Cardinality post-aggregator. You should be able to set your having clause on the result of the post-aggregator.
